document.title: reStructuredText Test Document
reStructuredText Test Document
document.subtitle: Examples of Syntax Constructs

meta.content: A test document, containing at least one example of each reStructuredText construct.
meta.name: description

docinfo.author: David Goodger
docinfo.address: 123 Example Street Example, EX Canada A1B 2C3
docinfo.date: Now, or yesterday. Or maybe even before yesterday.
docinfo.revision: is managed by a version control system.
docinfo.copyright: This document has been placed in the public domain. You may do with it as you wish. You may copy, modify, redistribute, reattribute, sell, buy, rent, lease, destroy, or improve it, quote it at length, excerpt, incorporate, collate, fold, staple, or mutilate it, or do anything else to it that your or anyone else's heart desires.

field_body.paragraph: Generic bibliographic fields may contain multiple body elements.

topic.title: Abstract
topic.paragraph: This is a test document, containing at least one example of each reStructuredText construct.

document.comment: This is a comment. Note how any initial comments are moved by transforms to after the document title, subtitle, and docinfo.
Above is the document title, and below is the subtitle. They are transformed from section titles after parsing.
bibliographic fields (which also require a transform):

section.title: 1.1 Section Title
section.subtitle: Section Subtitle
section.paragraph: Lone subsections are converted to a section subtitle by a transform activated with the --section-subtitles command line option or the sectsubtitle-xform configuration value.

section.title: 1.3 Transitions
section.paragraph: Here's a transition:
It divides the section. Transitions may also occur between sections:

section.title: 2.1 Paragraphs
section.paragraph: A paragraph.

section.title: 2.1.1 Inline Markup
section.paragraph: Paragraphs contain text and may contain inline markup: emphasis, strong emphasis, inline literals, standalone hyperlinks (http://www.python.org), external hyperlinks (Python 5), internal cross-references (example), external hyperlinks with embedded URIs (Python web site), anonymous hyperlink references 5 (a second reference 7), footnote references (manually numbered 1, anonymous auto-numbered 3, labeled auto-numbered 2, or symbolic *), citation references (see CIT2002), substitution references ( & a trimmed heart (U+2665):♥), and inline hyperlink targets (see Targets below for a reference back to here). Character-level inline markup is also possible (although exceedingly ugly!) in reStructuredText. Problems are indicated by |problematic| text (generated by processing errors; this one is intentional). Here is a reference to the doctitle and the subtitle.

The default role for interpreted text is Title Reference. Here are some explicit interpreted text roles: a PEP reference (PEP 287); an RFC reference (RFC 2822); an abbreviation (abb.), an acronym (reST), code (print "hello world"); a subscript; a superscript and explicit roles for Docutils' standard inline markup.
section.comment: DO NOT RE-WRAP THE FOLLOWING PARAGRAPH!
section.paragraph: Let's test wrapping and whitespace significance in inline literals: This is an example of --inline-literal --text, --including some-- strangely--hyphenated-words. Adjust-the-width-of-your-browser-window to see how the text is wrapped. -- ---- -------- Now note the spacing between the words of this sentence (words should be grouped in pairs).
If the --pep-references option was supplied, there should be a live link to PEP 258 here.

list_item.paragraph: This nested list should be compacted by the HTML writer.
list_item.comment: Even if this item contains a target and a comment.

field_body.paragraph: Field lists map field names to field bodies, like database records. They are often part of an extension syntax. They are an unambiguous variant of RFC 2822 fields.
The field marker is a colon, the field name, and a colon.
The field body may contain one or more body elements, indented relative to the field marker.
This paragraph has the credits class set. (This is actually not about credits but just for ensuring that the class attribute doesn't get stripped away.)

section.title: 2.6 Option Lists
section.paragraph: For listing command-line options:

description.paragraph: options can have arguments and long descriptions
long options can also have arguments
The description can also start on the next line.
The description may contain multiple body elements, regardless of where it starts.
Option argumens must start with a letter or be wrapped in angle brackets.
Angle brackets are also required if an option expects more than one argument.

section.paragraph: There must be at least two spaces between the option and the description.

section.title: 2.7 Literal Blocks
section.paragraph: Literal blocks are indicated with a double-colon ("::") at the end of the preceding paragraph (over there -->). They can be indented:
section.literal_block: if literal_block: text = 'is left as-is' spaces_and_linebreaks = 'are preserved' markup_processing = None
section.paragraph: Or they can be quoted without indentation:
section.literal_block: >> Great idea! > > Why didn't I think of that?

section.title: 2.8 Line Blocks
section.paragraph: This section tests line blocks. Line blocks are body elements which consist of lines and other line blocks. Nested line blocks cause indentation.

line_block.line: This is a line block. It ends with a blank line.
New lines begin with a vertical bar ("|").
Line breaks and initial indent are significant, and preserved.
Continuation lines are also possible. A long line that is intended to wrap should begin with a space in place of the vertical bar.
The left edge of a continuation line need not be aligned with the left edge of the text above it.
This is a second line block.
Blank lines are permitted internally, but they must begin with a "|".

section.paragraph: Another line block, surrounded by paragraphs:

line_block.line: And it's no good waiting by the window
It's no good waiting for the sun
Please believe me, the things you dream of
They don't fall in the lap of no-one

section.paragraph: Take it away, Eric the Orchestra Leader!

line_block.line: A one, two, a one two three four
Half a bee, philosophically,
must, ipso facto, half not be.
But half the bee has got to be,
vis a vis its entity. D'you see?
But can a bee be said to be
or not to be an entire bee,
when half the bee is not a bee,
due to some ancient injury?
Singing...

section.paragraph: A line block, like the following poem by Christian Morgenstern, can also be centre-aligned:

line_block.line: Zwei Trichter wandeln durch die Nacht.
Durch ihres Rumpfs verengten Schacht
fließt weißes Mondlicht
still und heiter
auf ihren
Waldweg
u. s.
w.

section.title: 2.9 Block Quotes
section.paragraph: Block quotes consist of indented body elements:

block_quote.paragraph: My theory by A. Elk. Brackets Miss, brackets. This theory goes as follows and begins now. All brontosauruses are thin at one end, much much thicker in the middle and then thin again at the far end. That is my theory, it is mine, and belongs to me and I own it, and what it is too.

section.paragraph: The language of a quote (like any other object) can be specified by a class attribute:

block_quote.paragraph: ReStructuredText est un langage de balisage léger utilisé notamment dans la documentation du langage Python.

section.title: 2.10 Doctest Blocks
section.doctest_block: >>> print 'Python-specific usage examples; begun with ">>>"' Python-specific usage examples; begun with ">>>" >>> print '(cut and pasted from interactive Python sessions)' (cut and pasted from interactive Python sessions)

footnote.paragraph: A footnote contains body elements, consistently indented by at least 1 space.
This is the footnote's second paragraph.

Footnotes may be numbered, either manually (as in 1) or automatically using a "#"-prefixed label. This footnote has a label so it can be referred to from multiple places, both as a footnote reference (2) and as a hyperlink reference.
This footnote is numbered automatically and anonymously using a label of "#" only.
And this is the third paragraph.
Footnotes may also use symbols, specified with a "*" label. Here's a reference to the next footnote: †.
This footnote shows the next symbol in the sequence.
Here's an unreferenced footnote, with a reference to a nonexistent footnote: [5]_.

section.title: 2.12 Citations

citation.label: CIT2002
citation.paragraph: Citations are text-labeled footnotes. They may be rendered separately and differently from footnotes.

section.paragraph: Here's a reference to the above, CIT2002, and a [nonexistent]_ citation.

section.title: 2.13 Targets
section.paragraph: This paragraph is pointed to by the explicit "example" target. A reference can be found under Inline Markup, above. Inline hyperlink targets are also possible.
Section headers are implicit targets, referred to by name. See Targets, which is a subsection of Body Elements.
Explicit external targets are interpolated into references such as "Python 5".
Targets may be indirect and anonymous. Thus this phrase may also refer to the Targets section.
Here's a `hyperlink reference without a target`_, which generates an error.

section.title: 2.13.1 Duplicate Target Names
section.paragraph: Duplicate names in section headers or other implicit targets will generate "info" (level-1) system messages. Duplicate names in explicit targets will generate "warning" (level-2) system messages.

section.title: 2.13.2 Duplicate Target Names
section.paragraph: Since there are two "Duplicate Target Names" section headers, we cannot uniquely refer to either of them by name. If we try to (like this: `Duplicate Target Names`_), an error is generated.

section.title: 2.14 Directives
section.paragraph: These are just a sample of the many reStructuredText Directives. For others, please see reStructuredText Directives 8.

section.title: 2.14.1 Document Parts
section.paragraph: An example of the "contents" directive can be seen above this section (a local, untitled table of contents) and at the beginning of the document (a document-wide table of contents).

section.title: 2.14.2 Images and Figures
section.paragraph: An image directive (also clickable -- a hyperlink reference):
Image with multiple IDs:

image.names: image\ target\ 3 image\ target\ 2 image\ target\ 1

section.paragraph: A centered image:
A left-aligned image:
This paragraph might flow around the image. The specific behavior depends upon the style sheet and the browser or rendering software used.
A right-aligned image:
This paragraph might flow around the image. The specific behavior depends upon the style sheet and the browser or rendering software used.
For inline images see Substitution Definitions.
Image size:
An image 2 em wide:
An image 2 cm wide and 15 pixel high:
Relative units allow adaption of the image to the screen or paper size. An image occupying 50% of the line width:
A figure is an image with a caption and/or a legend. With page-based output media, figures might float to a different position if this helps the page layout.

figure.caption: Plaintext markup syntax and parser system.

legend.paragraph: This paragraph is also part of the legend.

section.paragraph: A left-aligned figure, 70% wide:

legend.paragraph: The legend may consist of several paragraphs.

section.paragraph: This paragraph might flow around the figure.
The specific behavior depends upon the style sheet and the browser or rendering software used.
A centred figure, 40% wide:

legend.paragraph: The legend may consist of several paragraphs.

section.paragraph: This paragraph might flow around the figure.
The specific behavior depends upon the style sheet and the browser or rendering software used.
A right-aligned figure:

legend.paragraph: The legend may consist of several paragraphs.

section.paragraph: This paragraph might flow around the figure. The specific behavior depends upon the style sheet and the browser or rendering software used.

section.title: 2.14.3 Tables
section.paragraph: Tables may be given titles and additional arguments with the table directive:
With the "widths" argument "auto" (or "class" value "colwidths-auto"), column widths are determined by the backend (if supported by the writer/backend).

hint.paragraph: It's bigger than a bread box.

warning.paragraph: Strong prose may provoke extreme mental exertion. Reader discretion is strongly advised.

admonition.title: And, by the way...
admonition.paragraph: You can make up your own admonition too.

section.title: 2.14.5 Topics, Sidebars, and Rubrics
section.paragraph: Sidebars are like miniature, parallel documents.

sidebar.title: Optional Sidebar Title
sidebar.subtitle: Optional Subtitle
sidebar.paragraph: This is a sidebar. It is for text outside the flow of the main text.
sidebar.rubric: This is a rubric inside a sidebar
sidebar.paragraph: Sidebars often appear beside the main text with a border and a different background or font color.

section.paragraph: A topic is like a block quote with a title, or a self-contained section with no subsections.
A rubric is like an informal heading that doesn't correspond to the document's structure. It is typically highlighted in red (hence the name).
Topics and rubrics can be used at places where a section title is not allowed (e.g. inside a directive).

section.title: 2.14.7 Replacement Text
section.paragraph: I recommend you try Python, the best language around 5.

section.title: 2.14.8 Compound Paragraph
section.paragraph: The compound directive is used to create a "compound paragraph", which is a single logical paragraph containing multiple physical body elements. For example:

compound.paragraph: The 'rm' command is very dangerous. If you are logged in as root and enter
you will erase the entire contents of your file system.

section.paragraph: Test the handling and display of compound paragraphs:

compound.paragraph: Compound 3, only consisting of one paragraph.

compound.literal_block: Compound 4. This one starts with a literal block.
compound.paragraph: Compound 4, paragraph following the literal block.

section.paragraph: Now something really perverted -- a nested compound block. This is just to test that it works at all; the results don't have to be meaningful.

compound.paragraph: Compound 7, tests the inclusion of various block-level elements in one logical paragraph. First a table,

entry.paragraph: Middle cell, consisting of exactly one paragraph.

compound.paragraph: followed by a paragraph. This physical paragraph is actually a continuation of the paragraph before the table. It is followed by

line_block.line: a line
block,

compound.paragraph: a paragraph followed by a comment,
and the final paragraph of the compound 7.

section.title: 2.14.9 Parsed Literal Blocks
section.literal_block:
This is a parsed literal block. This line is indented. The next line is blank.
Inline markup is supported, e.g. emphasis, strong, literal text, sub- and superscripts, inline formulas: A = 2 \pi r^2, footnotes 1, hyperlink targets, and references.

section.title: 2.14.10 Code
section.paragraph: Blocks of source code can be set with the code directive. If the code language is specified, the content is parsed and tagged by the Pygments 6 syntax highlighter and can be formatted with a style sheet. (Code parsing is turned off using the syntax-highlight config setting in the test conversions in order to get identical results with/without installed Pygments highlighter.)
The :number-lines: option (with optional start value) generates line numbers:
section.literal_block: 8 # print integers from 0 to 9: 9 for i in range(10): 10 print i
section.paragraph: For inline code snippets, there is the code role, which can be used directly (the code will not be parsed/tagged, as the language is not known) or as base for special code roles, e.g. the LaTeX code in the next paragraph.
Docutils uses LaTeX syntax for math directives and roles: \alpha = f(x) prints \alpha = f(x).
The :code: option of the include directive sets the included content as a code block, here the rst file header_footer.rst with line numbers:
section.literal_block: 1 .. header:: Document header 2 .. footer:: Document footer

section.title: 2.14.11 Meta
section.paragraph: The “meta” directive 9 is used to specify metadata to be stored in, e.g., HTML META tags or ODT file properties.

section.title: 2.15 Substitution Definitions
section.paragraph: An inline image () example:
A Unicode example:
(Substitution definitions are only visible in the rST source.)

section.title: 2.16 Comments
section.paragraph: Here's one:
section.comment:
Comments begin with two dots and a space. Anything may follow, except for the syntax of footnotes, hyperlink targets, directives, or substitution definitions.
Double-dashes -- "--" -- must be escaped somehow in HTML output.
Comments may contain non-ASCII characters: ä ö ü æ ø å
section.paragraph: (View the HTML/LaTeX/... source to see the comment.)

section.title: 2.17 Raw text
section.paragraph: This does not necessarily look nice, because there may be missing white space.
It's just there to freeze the behavior.
This is the fourth test with myrawroleclass set.

section.paragraph: This table has a cell spanning two columns:

section.title: 2.20 Rowspanning tables
section.paragraph: Here's a table with cells spanning several rows:

section.title: 2.21 Complex tables
section.paragraph: Here's a complex table, which should test all features.

section.title: 2.22 List Tables
section.paragraph: Here's a list table exercising all features:

entry.paragraph: If we took the bones out, it wouldn't be crunchy, now would it?

section.title: 3 Error Handling
section.paragraph: Any errors caught during processing will generate system messages.
There should be five messages in the following, auto-generated section, "Docutils System Messages":
section.comment: section should be added by Docutils automatically

system_message.paragraph: Unknown target name: "hyperlink reference without a target".
Duplicate target name, cannot be used as a unique reference: "duplicate target names".
